channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [AVRO-1836] avro schema compatibility checking does not work for records.
item.description:
Hi Guys,

We found a problem on avro 1.8.0 when calling avro's compatibility checking.
Specifically, we used the function checkReaderWriterCompatibility,
it works with no problem when we provides simple schema, like oldschema=

{"type":"int"}

schema=

{"type":"long"}

, but when we use complicated schema, like
oldschema={"type":"record","name":"twitter","fields":[

{"name":"username","type":"string"}

]}

schema={"type":"record","name":"twitter","fields":[

{"name":"username","type":"string"}

]}

it reports that record name(twitter in this case) cannot be redefined.
When one rename the second schema, it told me the two schema are not compatible. Actually, for the completed case, oldschema and schema are exactly the same, the output is expected to be compatible.

Do you guys have any ideas about this?

Thanks, Yan
item.summary: avro schema compatibility checking does not work for records.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Yan Cui, it looks like you probably used the same Schema parser for both strings, which would end up attempting to redefine the schema because the parser keeps track of Schemas it has parsed so that others can reference them by name. I don't think your error is coming from the compatibility check. If you have a stack trace, that would show where the exception is coming from.

Hi Ryan, thanks for your reply!
It solves our problem. Does it make sense to support just one parser (instead of two)?
Without your help, it 's really easy to use it wrongly, although I do not have
the data of how many people make exactly the same mistake.

Yan Cui, I think the Schema.Parser javadoc is pretty clear that the parser instance keeps references like this:

A parser for JSON-format schemas. Each named schema parsed with a parser is added to the names known to the parser so that subsequently parsed schemas may refer to it by name.

Do you think we should change that? What would have helped you in this case?
Thanks for posting me the javadoc, that makes sense.

item.title: [AVRO-1837] Add support for logical date, time, timestamp type for python AVRO
item.description: Currently, python Avro does not seem to support a TIME, TIMESTAMP and DATE logicalType type.
item.summary: Add support for logical date, time, timestamp type for python AVRO

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
GitHub user abrarsheikh opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/avro/pull/89

AVRO-1837 Add support for Date, Time and Timestamp Logical Type in python Avro

Need to be reviewed by : @clin7 @justinmcunn @premsantosh

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/abrarsheikh/avro time_dt_ts_support_new

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/avro/pull/89.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #89

item.title: [AVRO-1838] Ensure Checkstyle enforces trailing spaces rule
item.description:
Followup of AVRO-1828
We want to make sure the code stays as clean as possible by ensuring that Checkstyle fails the build if they are present.

The checkstyle maven module describes how to do this in a multi module project (like avro):
https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-checkstyle-plugin/examples/multi-module-config.html
item.summary: Ensure Checkstyle enforces trailing spaces rule

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
This patch is a first quick draft of making Checkstyle work.
Reality of this first one it that the build fails over a lot of errors regarding RedundantModifier: Redundant 'public' modifier.
If I disable that check the build succeeds.

Note that RedundantThrows module has been completely remove from recent versions of Checkstyle.

I had a good look at the problem cases reported by RedundantModifier.
I'm a practical programmer and I consider this error "not important enough to worry about".
So I removed that entry and this passes the build.
Yet when I introduce a trailing space somewhere it fails (as desired).

I agree about not worrying about the redundant modifier.

Why does the current patch introduce a new maven module? Can't all of the Java code inherit from the lang/java/pom.xml? I don't see a compelling reason to move everything, but I'm not sure what your reasoning was.

The simple reason to move it was because the maven site explicitly showed that as the way to do this. (see link earlier)
I'm fine with any implementation strategy that works.

As far as I understand the reasons have to do with putting the config xml on the classpath and the way this plugin works.
Cleanup of the patch.

Commit 02f623bfe62fd35914b41a8727e041de70635655 in avro's branch refs/heads/master from Ryan Blue
[ https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=avro.git;h=02f623b ]

AVRO-1838: Java: Update checkstyle to catch trailing whitespace. Contributed by Niels Basjes.
Sounds fine to me. Looks like it keeps the checkstyle stuff all contained, too.
I just committed this. Thanks Niels Basjes!

Commit bedf2f21a05715c3c1aa3b151329f2368c43c965 in avro's branch refs/heads/master from Niels Basjes
[ https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=avro.git;h=bedf2f2 ]

AVRO-1838: Java: Update checkstyle to catch trailing whitespace. Added missing files.

item.title: [AVRO-1839] Update the gitignore files to hide generated files
item.description: After doing a ./build.sh clean test dist rat there are a lot of files and directories with generated files that are not ignored right now.
item.summary: Update the gitignore files to hide generated files

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Has updated and new .gitignore files (mostly on a per language basis)
One extra change to fix a missing rat entry.

+1

Thanks for doing so much work to clean up the builds! This is great. Do you know if all of these are removed by `./build.sh clean`? Since you just came up with the list of build-created files, it may be a good time for us to update that.

Committed.
I created a followup issue to make sure a build.sh clean really cleans it up: AVRO-1840
